awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Coupling and Cohesion as Factors Affecting Vulnerability to Abrupt Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Benjamin Vining, of the University of Arkansas-Fayetteville, along with collaborators from the University of Louisiana-Lafayette, the University of Florida-Gainesville, and in Peru, will examine how the organization of different agricultural production systems relates to climate change vulnerabilities.  Climate change is increasingly a public and policy concern. This research will focus on understanding how different agricultural strategies were used as el Nino disasters occurred in the past with changing frequency and strength.  Understanding how agriculturalists switched between productive strategies will improve long-term adaptations to climate change, provide theoretical and applied models for how to address climate change in future planning and development, and promote local adaptive capacities.  Using agriculture as a set of case studies, these models can be generalized to other forms of economic networks to understand how various strategies can promote resilience. This project will establish new multidisciplinary approaches to tackle such complex problems as climate change adaptation, and train graduate students from the partner institutions and countries in international collaborations. 
 
Dr. Vining and his team will examine how prehispanic agriculturalists developed and switched between various productive strategies as the el Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) changed in frequency and severity.  The study region, north coastal Peru, hosted a series of civilizations between approximately 2000 BC - 1450 AD, including the Moche, Lambayeque, and Chimu societies.  However, the region is also particularly vulnerable to el Nino induced disasters, such as occurred recently in 2016-2017.  Initial archaeological work in this region indicates that prehispanic agriculture was based on a suite of strategies.  The complex economies that supported prehispanic societies were based on in part on switching amongst agricultural strategies as climatic contexts shifted.  The researchers come from the fields of archaeology, paleolimnology and palaeoclimate, and ecological modeling. A principal objective will be to combine high-precision dating of agricultural systems with paleoclimate conditions reconstructed from lake cores.  The researchers will use this multidisplinary methodological background to improve historic reconstructions of past ENSO variations, record archaeological examples of agricultural technologies in their environmental context, and reconstruct how different strategies were employed as ENSO effected climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project combined archaeological field survey and absolute dating methods with paleolimnological analysis and geospatial modeling to investigate how past societies in the Chicama Valley on the North Coast of Peru responded to variable climate from the mid-Holocene (ca. 2500 BCE) through European arrival (1532 CE). It focused on agricultural production as a key activity very directly linked, on the arid Peruvian littoral, to climate conditions. By examining both relict agricultural features and changing settlement patterns over time, this project aimed to explore how past societies in the region adapted to variable climates.

To this end, the project re-examined existing archaeological survey data produced by several previous projects beginning in the mid-20th century, and developed a novel strategy of radiocarbon dating in order to help integrate these legacy data. This process of data integration required development of a new tool for harmonization of legacy data, future versions of which will be available to other researchers facing comparable tasks. Similarly, the methodology developed for direct-dating of adobe architecture, prevalent on the arid Peruvian coast, will be publicly disseminated for use by other researchers.

Rebuilding the valley chronology enabled the pairing of these data on the history of settlement and agricultural practice with regional (pre-existing) and local (project-produced) paleoclimate reconstructions, including estimates of El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) frequency. By juxtaposing these two lines of evidence, the project was able to demonstrate that areas of the Chicama Valley that were never irrigable nevertheless comprised an important element of past agricultural strategies. These results informed spatially explicit modeling of agricultural suitability (Fig. 1), with which the project continues to assess the relationship between settlement and cultivation decisions and environmental changes in the region.  

The strategies for leveraging legacy data and efficiently documenting and sampling archaeological sites that this project developed can be adopted by researchers in other contexts, while the modeling approach can inform investigations of responses to climatic change in other arid regions affected by ENSO, and dynamic environments more generally. This project created collaborative research relationships between the University of Florida, University of Arkansas, SUNY Albany, and the Museo Arqueológico del Complejo el Brujo (Peru). The project has so far resulted in seven conference papers, four scientific papers, and experiential learning opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in Peru and the U.S.
